author: jakeypoos87
title: Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice!
review:
Lego dimensions set 71349: Beetlejuice fun pack retails for £14.99 and includes 56 pieces with a 3 in 1 build with the sand worm that looks very cool and has some good movement in the body and the mouth that looks very accurate to the film. The sand worm is defiantly one of the best of the  dimensions builds. The minfigure of Beetlejuice is exclusive to this set and he has some amazing printing on the torso and legs and also has a duel sided face print with an angry and happy face. His hair piece is a recolor of the Doc Brown hair piece in green and it is a very accurate fit for the minifig.

Overall this set is very cool because the Beetlejuice minifigue is very accurate and  awesome to get, also the build for the sandworm is a great build that looks awesome. I would recommend this set if you are fan of the film and want the character and I  also recommend it for people who wan to play it in the game and is definatley  worth the money.

author: Odeinoichus
title: Beetlejuice or Betelgeuse?
review:
Set #71349 Beetlejuice Fun Pack: Though I venture someplace scary and I know I should be wary, evil hauntings I turn loose… Beetlejuice, Beetlejuice, BEETLEJUICE!!!

For this final set from LEGO Dimensions it feels appropriate that we end on a high note. As this is the last set to be reviewed let us discuss it positively, because it is quite positive. Note, however, it is still just a Fun Pack. So we won’t be seeing a whole lot of content.

Packaging

The model graveyard from the movie is seen quite prominently behind a shrugging Beetlejuice, as if to say, come on… You know you want to unlock me in this game. So just go and do it! Come on you little flesh stain! At this point I should remind everyone that Beetlejuice isn’t entirely age appropriate at times. While there was a popular cartoon based on it the film was far more risqué and this set is based on the film.

Parts

This set features a host of white, green and black elements to make tons of ghoulish monstrosities. As well as Beetlejuice’s greatest fear, but it doesn’t offer too many unique elements aside from the printed toy tag of the Ghost with the Most.

Minifigures

Beetlejuice: Sporting a chique prison stripe suit with tie, this ghoulish fiend is covered in rot and slime on both sides of his facial print. With a light lime greenish hair piece re-used from Doc Brown, this spooky spectral menace has arm printing and leg printing which ends just below the knee. Not sure why they didn’t print his feet too, it looks a little odd seeing it that way. Still, it could be worse I suppose. No accessories unfortunately, it might have been nice to get our first LEGO beetle, oh well, perhaps another time.

The build

Saturn’s Sandworm: The deadly menace from the climax of the movie arises in LEGO toy form and to build it you need the help of some hinge bricks. This model is only a small portion of the creature, complete with head, but it does work quite well. The build is quick and enjoyable.

Spooky Spider: This creature build is not accurate, it only has four legs, so it definitely isn’t a proper spider. But this is a very clever re-use of parts, really fun re-build that works well.

Haunted Vacuum: Oh dear, this build is even better than the last. Old school vacuum cleaners are awesome and this overgrown tooth filled model is a great one to build, loved the look of it and it was a pretty solid build.

The completed model

Saturn’s Sandworm & Alternate Models: Everything about these three models is perfectly ghastly, and that’s a good thing with Beetlejuice. The Sandworm looks great, the detail is perfect and the double mouth gimmick of the stop-motion creature is accurately depicted. The Spooky Spider is a bit questionable, but it’s very impressive. It is a bit on the weaker side compared to the other two models, but that is nothing to be concerned with, because it is still a solid little model.

The Haunted Vacuum is just awesome, I love the quirky nature of it considering it’s a massive vacuum cleaner, I mean it’s taller than a Minifigure, meaning it would never work for anybody.

The Digital Content

Adventure World: Made of three distinct areas, the Beetlejuice adventure world is gorgeous. There was no glitching in this world from what I can recall. You explore the outside of the Deetz home somewhere in the wastes of Saturn. Once inside you get to visit some of the rooms and solve puzzles as with most of the places in LEGO Dimensions. Journey to the attic and you can visit the third and final big area of the world and movie. The massive model of the town. All of this area is just loads of fun and it was a thrill to explore it all fully.

Battle Arena: Journey to Beetlejuice Saturn, which I suspect is similar to the adventure world exterior design. Honestly I’m not sure, I never actually went to this battle arena so I’m guessing as to what it looks like. If you want to play with three friends in the world of Beetlejuice, you can definitely check out this battle arena.

Character & Vehicle Abilities: Beetlejuice has some pretty solid abilities quite fitting of the character. He can destroy Cracked LEGO Objects, access Mini Access doors, use magic, mind control and illumination. A really interesting combination of abilities.

Saturn’s Sandworm has Sonar Smash. A single ability which is extremely useful. To Spooky Spider can destroy Gold and Silver LEGO Objects has the Tow-Bar ability of all things and a Super Jump. Pretty crazy abilities right, but wait, access the Haunted Vacuum and you’ll get the power to destroy Red Demon Objects, add the Special Weapon ability, keep Super Jump and then have the Enhanced Stud Attraction. A pity you probably won’t need tons of studs at this point to access anything. Overall a solid selection of abilities.

Overall opinion

Well, it has finally come. The discussion of the last LEGO Dimensions set. Although I do have plans to review the digital content of the two Polybags, which I have yet to own. (Yet still hope to someday.) I dig this set, the digital content is awesome and the physical content is just a great level of fun. I’d recommend it strongly to add to your LEGO Dimensions collection. It’s also great to see a Tim Burton property in LEGO video game form. Here’s hoping that someday we may see a LEGO Disney inspired game with Nightmare Before Christmas and other movies added for a LEGO Dimensions type collision of worlds. Perhaps inspired by Kingdom Hearts. Strongly Recommended.

author: Lobo_da_boss_
title: The only completely overpriced theme
review:
Opening;

The beetlejuice film is one I very much enjoy and that is why I go this set but looking back I now realise how overpriced this theme was as a whole .

The Minifigures-

The figure has a very nice recolour of doc Brown's hair piece and has a double sided face with a happy face and an annoyed expression , his torso is also great and the arms have a great print and finally the legs are very good as well . The stand is the regular dimensions stand and has a very cool beetlejuice print on it .

The build-

The build depicts the Saturn sand worm fairly well and has a very nice arching technique and a has with sharp teeth and a head with yellow eyes  also I like the detail of the fact it all tests on a 2×3 light tan plate above the dimensions stand .

In conclusion-

this a good set but £15 uk is a terrible price but I do wish I got other packs like the goonies ( my favourite film) , both back to the future ones , the gremlins one an the ET one . Keeping in mind I never played the game as gaming is not an interest of mine but maybe this is worth it for the game but for me it's mainly the figure and build .
